div1.p: Peak informs Carter of stories she submitted to various newspapers. She is sorry to hear Carter is ill.

div1.head: Letter from Mayme Ober Peak to Laura Armistead Carter, December 12, [19--]
div1.p:
Today I received six extra copies of
my story - after ten days and writing
twice. Am sending you 3, have sent
one to Cousin Mary (had already sent
a copy to Cousin Laurie) and am
retaining one for myself. Also sent copy
to Cousin Hugh Lawson Rose.

I re-wrote the beginning of the
story, and sent it again to the New York
Times, suggesting it for their book
review section. This was a week ago
and as it has not been returned, I hope
they are using it. Will let you know
when I'm advised. I sent the only
photograph I had to the Globe, and
will have to call on you for an
extra one if the Times wants it.

I am also enclosing portion of
a letter from Virginia Wilcox Stroeban
(sister of Judge Wilcox; her mother
was a Claiborne) which explains itself.
I wrote her to call on you while in
Norfolk. Am so sorry to hear you
are laid up - but, my dear child, I
only wonder that you stood up so
long! Do give in and take a good,
complete rest, you will be able to do
ten times as much when you get up.

I have been in bed all this week.
Overdid last week on a rush story
and took cold also in my “downstairs”
so am resting in bed. Nothing serious,
however. Chest condition generally
is wonderfully improved.

I wrote Earnlay Edwards to drop in
to cheer you up sometimes, as I
imagine, even with all your friends,
you miss your “Comrade” more and
more. She always has a lot of sprightly
gossip, and is amusing and entertaining.

Write me when you are better
and when you have anything interesting
to read, do send it to me and I
will carefully return. I have practically
devoured Fred's library here.

closer.salute:
With love from Mother and
me.
Aff'ly.
